Package pr1.helper.extension

Class Range

  • java.lang.Object
    • pr1.helper.extension.Range
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Character>
    public class Range
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Character>
    A utility class that represents an inclusive range of characters and enables iteration over that range using a for-each loop.

    This class supports construction from either char values or int values (which are cast to char). The range is inclusive on both ends, meaning both the start and end characters are part of the iteration.

    Example usage: 

    
 for (char c : new Range('a', 'z')) {
     System.out.println(c);
 }
    Since:
    2025
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Benjamin Wagner
    See Also:
    Iterator

    • Constructor Detail

      • Range

        public Range​(char start,
             char endInclusive)
        Constructs a Range from the specified start and end characters (inclusive).
        Parameters:
        start - the first character in the range
        endInclusive - the last character in the range (included in iteration)

      • Range

        public Range​(int start,
             int endInclusive)
        Constructs a Range from the specified integer values, which are cast to char.

        This is a convenience constructor for creating character ranges using integer literals (e.g., ASCII codes). Note that values outside the valid char range (0â€“65535) will be silently truncated due to Javaâ€™s narrowing primitive conversion.

        Parameters:
        start - the numeric representation of the first character
        endInclusive - the numeric representation of the last character (inclusive)

    • Method Detail

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Character> iterator()
        Returns an iterator over the characters in this range, from start to endInclusive, inclusive.

        The iterator produces characters in ascending order. If start is greater than endInclusive, the iterator will have no elements.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Character>
        Returns:
        an Iterator over the character range
